11.title: "Faites vos Jeux"
11.author: scénario, H
11.appears_in: G. Oesterheld ; dessin, Breccia ; traduction, Mercedes Gonzales ; lettrage, Nadège Gaudin. p. 50-57 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 3 (Jan. 1998).
notes: Translation of "Hagan Juegos" (Sherlock Time), originally published in Hora Cero. Story, takes place in the year 2005 A.D.
Introduced by José Muñoz.

English summary (from p. 139): "Sherlock Time. The late and regretted Alberto Breccia, in whose lineage José Muñoz situates himself, obtained his first success with this series. We have translated an episode from 1959, the originals of which are in the Museum of Comics' collections."

36.heading: Breccia, Alberto, 1919-1993--Articles About.
36.title: "Comienza una Historia"
36.author: Norberto Buscaglia
36.appears_in: p. 55-64 in La Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios sobre la Historieta, v. 1, no. 1 (Abril 2001).
notes: Resumen: "Sin duda, no fue fácil para Alberto Breccia dejar de lado las comodidades que produce el mantenerse dentro de los esquemas que un orden establecido determina. No es sencillo asumir que uno puede cambiar algo, si se lo propone. Dicho de otra manera: ser un revolucionario en su campo. Y el campo de acción de Alberto Breccia fue la historieta. Un género que, nacido a fines del siglo XIX, aún tiene mucho por dar en el siglo XXI."

Abstract: Surely it was not easy for Alberto Breccia to put aside the comfort and support that comes from working inside an established system. One cannot simply assume that one can change something just by intending to. Said another way: to be a revolutionary in his field. And the field of action for Alberto Breccia was the comics. A medium that was born at the end of the nineteenth century, and has a lot to give in the twenty-first.
"Continuará."
Abstracts as printed with the article, with some editing of the English.
Includes illustrations.

129.heading: Breeding.
129.title: "The Greatest Thief in the Universe!"
129.author: Paul Kupperburg(!), writer ; Curt Swan, penciller ; Bob Oksner, inker ; Ed King, letterer ; Gene D'Angelo, colorist ; Julius Schwartz, editor
notes: Summary (by Mary Walker): The Thief-Master of Ramox begins a series of thefts: sulfer, matches, polonium, tellurium and tungsten. Kent thinks there must be a pattern which would include his encounter with a space ship the day before in which the ship disappeared. The Thief-Master is from a race in which criminal tendencies had been bred out generations before but he is a genetic atavism. He refuses to consult his family because the shame to them but the Healer thinks of a plan. Superman is unable to stop the next theft, of selenium, and meets the thief only to have him escape but gets a clue to where the thief will strike next: Molybdenum. He sets a successful trap and the thief's entire demeanor changes. The doctor's theory was that the genetic compulsion would end if he were captured against his will.
